>So said Mike Bresnahan on 2003-06-20 --------------------
>A problem that =
I am very often faced with is writing some code that
>interacts with a 3rd =
party API which I am unfamiliar with.  In these cases
>it seems counter pro=
ductive to create unit tests for my own code when I
>have
>no idea whether =
my code will actually work when used with the 3rd party
>API.
>I could end =
up wasting a lot time writing and testing code that is designed
>incorrectl=
y.  In these cases, it seems more sensical to me to write
>integration test=
s which involve both my code and the 3rd party API.  How do
>people more fa=
miliar with unit testing handle such situations?

Google "Learning Tests".
=

In short, the idea is to formalize how you think the third-party API behav=
es in tests, then using that information with confidence to write your own =
objects. It's not something that one strictly follows, necessarily, but the=
re is one definite advantage to writing Learning Tests.

When I worked at I=
BM, my component used third-party software from HNC Software. I would typic=
ally test my code using my knowledge of how HNC's software works. Of course=
, my knowledge was imperfect, and occasionally the whole would not work eve=
n though the parts did. (Here I use "work" to mean "behave as expected".) O=
bviously some expectation of mine was incorrect, so I began writing Learnin=
g Tests against HNC's product, which both verified my assumptions and codif=
ied them for the next poor sap who has to maintain my software. In the proc=
ess, I wrote a failing test, which I shipped to HNC and which they used to =
fix the problem within two days. 

The key here is that I gave them a faili=
ng test, rather than a vague description of the problem. That eliminated th=
e cost figuring out just what I meant by "Blah blah blah doesn't do fizzlef=
azzle." They commented that having the failing test allowed them to fix the=
 problem in an hour and that the two-day turnaround was the result of their=
 laborious release process.

So Learning Tests gave me a few things:

* An =
unambiguous specification of the assumptions that underlie my code
* A way =
to verify my assumptions against the product I'm using
* An unambiguous way=
 to communicate problems to the company providing the software to me

Based=
 on that, I considered the technique a winner.
